content.title: von Willebrand Disease
content.summary: von Willebrand disease (VWD) is the most common inherited bleeding disorder, affecting ~1% of the population. It results from quantitative or qualitative defects in von Willebrand factor (VWF), a glycoprotein essential for platelet adhesion and FVIII carrier function. VWD presents with mucocutaneous bleeding (epistaxis, menorrhagia, easy bruising) rather than the deep bleeding seen in hemophilia. Three major types exist based on VWF deficiency pattern. Treatment includes desmopressin (DDAVP) for mild cases and VWF-containing concentrates for severe disease.
key_points: Most common inherited bleeding disorder (~1% prevalence)
VWF has dual function: platelet adhesion AND FVIII carrier/stabilizer
Mucocutaneous bleeding pattern: epistaxis, menorrhagia, bruising, GI bleeding
Types: Type 1 (partial deficiency), Type 2 (qualitative defects), Type 3 (complete absence)
Labs: Low VWF antigen, low VWF activity (ristocetin cofactor), ± low FVIII
Treatment: DDAVP (releases VWF stores) for type 1; VWF concentrate for type 3
content.statement: von Willebrand disease is the most common inherited bleeding disorder caused by VWF deficiency or dysfunction, presenting with mucocutaneous bleeding, diagnosed by VWF antigen and activity assays, and managed with DDAVP or VWF-containing concentrates.

explanation.intuition: VWF is like molecular 'glue' that helps platelets stick to damaged vessel walls AND acts as a 'bodyguard' protecting factor VIII from degradation. Without VWF, platelets can't stick properly and FVIII gets broken down faster - causing both platelet-type and factor-type bleeding.
explanation.key_insight: The bleeding pattern in VWD is mucocutaneous (skin and mucosa) because VWF is critical for platelet function. This differs from hemophilia which causes deep bleeding (joints, muscles) due to coagulation factor deficiency. If a patient has nosebleeds and heavy periods, think VWD; if they have hemarthroses, think hemophilia.
explanation.technical_details: VWF is synthesized in endothelial cells and megakaryocytes; stored in Weibel-Palade bodies and platelet α-granules. VWF multimers bind platelet GPIb and collagen to mediate adhesion. VWF binds and stabilizes FVIII, extending its half-life from minutes to 12 hours. The VWF gene is on chromosome 12.

definitions_glossary.von_willebrand_factor: Glycoprotein essential for platelet adhesion and FVIII carrier function
definitions_glossary.von_willebrand_disease: Inherited bleeding disorder from VWF deficiency or dysfunction
definitions_glossary.ristocetin_cofactor_activity: Functional assay measuring VWF ability to agglutinate platelets
definitions_glossary.VWF_antigen: Immunologic measure of VWF protein quantity
definitions_glossary.DDAVP: Desmopressin; synthetic vasopressin analog releasing stored VWF from endothelium
definitions_glossary.mucocutaneous_bleeding: Bleeding from skin and mucous membranes; characteristic of platelet/VWF disorders
definitions_glossary.Weibel_Palade_bodies: Endothelial cell storage organelles containing VWF
definitions_glossary.FVIII: Factor VIII; coagulation factor stabilized by VWF
definitions_glossary.type_3_VWD: Complete VWF absence; severe, autosomal recessive
definitions_glossary.multimer_analysis: Gel electrophoresis of VWF to assess multimer distribution

VWF_functions.platelet_adhesion: VWF binds platelet GPIb to subendothelial collagen at high shear
VWF_functions.FVIII_carrier: VWF binds and stabilizes FVIII; protects from proteolytic degradation
VWF_functions.platelet_aggregation: Large VWF multimers enhance platelet plug formation

VWF_biology.multimers: High molecular weight multimers most hemostatically active

subtypes.2A: Decreased high MW multimers; reduced platelet binding
subtypes.2B: Enhanced GPIb binding; spontaneous platelet aggregation; thrombocytopenia
subtypes.2M: Decreased platelet binding with normal multimers
subtypes.2N: Decreased FVIII binding (Normandy); mimics mild hemophilia A

type_3.severity: Severe; joint and muscle bleeding (like hemophilia)

screening.PTT: Normal or prolonged (prolonged if FVIII low)

specialized_testing.RIPA: Ristocetin-induced platelet aggregation; enhanced in type 2B

confounders.blood_type: Type O has 25-30% lower VWF levels
confounders.stress_inflammation: VWF is acute phase reactant; levels rise with stress
confounders.pregnancy: VWF rises significantly; may normalize in late pregnancy

differential_diagnosis: Acquired von Willebrand syndrome (lymphoproliferative, cardiac disease)

DDAVP.mechanism: Releases stored VWF and FVIII from endothelium
DDAVP.indication: Type 1 VWD; some type 2 (do DDAVP trial first)
DDAVP.cautions: Tachyphylaxis with repeated dosing; hyponatremia risk

VWF_concentrates.indication: Type 3, severe type 2, DDAVP-unresponsive, major surgery

antifibrinolytics.indication: Adjunct for mucosal bleeding; dental procedures
antifibrinolytics.use: Often combined with DDAVP or factor concentrate

pregnancy_management.VWF_changes: VWF rises during pregnancy; may normalize by third trimester
pregnancy_management.delivery_planning: Check VWF levels at 34-36 weeks; epidural may be safe if VWF >50%
pregnancy_management.postpartum: VWF falls rapidly after delivery; monitor for delayed hemorrhage

definition.@value: The most common inherited bleeding disorder, caused by deficiency or dysfunction of von Willebrand factor, characterized by mucocutaneous bleeding

scopeNote.@value: Three major types with distinct mechanisms; DDAVP works for type 1

learning_objectives: Differentiate VWD from hemophilia based on bleeding pattern
Interpret VWF panel results and classify VWD type
Determine appropriate treatment based on VWD type
Recognize when to use DDAVP vs VWF concentrate
Manage VWD in pregnancy and surgical settings
clinical_pearls: Most common inherited bleeding disorder - 1% prevalence
Mucocutaneous bleeding (epistaxis, menorrhagia) vs hemophilia (joints, muscles)
DDAVP works for type 1; CONTRAINDICATED in type 2B (worsens thrombocytopenia)
Blood type O has 25-30% lower VWF - may cause false diagnosis
VWF rises in pregnancy - check levels at 34-36 weeks for delivery planning
common_misconceptions: VWD only affects women - affects both sexes equally, but menorrhagia brings women to attention earlier
Low VWF always means VWD - blood type O and stress can cause low VWF
DDAVP works for all VWD types - contraindicated in type 2B, ineffective in type 3

evidence.confidence_rationale: Well-established classification, diagnosis, and treatment algorithms

sources.source: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed. McGraw-Hill, 2022.
ASH ISTH NHF WFH 2021 guidelines on the diagnosis of von Willebrand disease
